awd_abstract_narration:
The Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory/Latino Initiative Program (SAO/LIP) offers year-long internship opportunities to undergraduate students belonging to minority groups.  The students are enrolled at local campuses of the University of Massachusetts (primarily UMass/Lowell).  Each intern is paired with a scientific advisor; they work together on a research project in which the student has expressed interest.  Students are also given training in programming, public speaking, and professional development.  Peer mentors are also available for support.  The students present the results of their work at national conferences.

The students are exposed to a wide range of outreach activities, including a job fair for people with disabilities and panel discussions on women and minorities in science.  One of the most important broader impacts of the project is the year-long exposure not only of the students to SAO researchers but also vice versa.

por.por_cntn:
Since 2015, the Smithsonian-UMASS LSAMP Latino Initiative Program (LIP) has offered unique summer research opportunities in astrophysical sciences, technology, and engineering at the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian for undergraduate students from the greater Boston area. The success of this program is due to its intentional focus on mentoring and the wide and adaptable research opportunities at the Center for Astrophysics (CfA). The LIP program excels as expanding access and building STEM identity among the participants through its intentional focus on mentoring and professional development. In post-experience surveys, students typically express an increased capacity for participating in STEM research and an increased sense of belonging to the STEM community. The students also recognize the impact of mentoring and professional development provided by the LIP program. This award, which covers the 2018-2023 intern cohorts, supported the summer research experiences of 33 undergraduate students enrolled in a variety of undergraduate degree programs from Boston-area universities. All of the students supported on this award identify as women and/or members of traditionally underrepresented racial and ethnic groups.  

Research at the CfA is state-of-the-art and encompasses a broad range of topics from Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics. Each LIP student participated in their own project of original research under the guidance of professional scientists, a STEM mentor, and a near Peer Mentor.  Throughout the summer, students participated in weekly professional development activities focused on building or strengthening professional skills. These professional development sessions included computer programming, resume building, interviewing, and scientific communication. Through these sessions and the network of mentors, students were exposed to a broad range of astronomer perspectives and career trajectories. Towards the end of each summer, the CfA hosted a scientific poster session that highlights the LIP student’s summer research. Additionally, LIP students participate and share the results of their summer research at the annual winter meeting of the American Astronomical Society (AAS).

Modified by: Rodolfo Montez
